question.content:
**Plot the image of point $A$ under a reflection across line $\ell$.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
A reflection moves a point perpendicularly across a line, so that the [[☃ definition 1]] is the same distance from the line as the [[☃ definition 2]], but on the other side.



[[☃ image 1]]

In other words, the line of reflection is the perpendicular bisector between any pair of corresponding points in the image and the pre-image.

The original figure *before* any transformations

options.alt: Point R is reflected across a line to form point R prime. Segment R R prime is perpendicular to the line.

hints.content: Point $A$ is $4$ units directly to the right of line $\ell$, so $A'$ will be $4$ units to the left of the line and have the same $y$-coordinate as $A$.

This is the image of point $A$:  



[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: Point A is reflected across vertical line l. The new point and point A are both four units from line l.

question.content:
Point $Q'$ is the image of $Q(3, -4)$ under a reflection across the $x$-axis.

**What are the coordinates of $Q'$?**

$($ [[☃ numeric-input 1]] $,$ [[☃ numeric-input 2]] $)$

hints.content:
A reflection moves a point perpendicularly across a line, so that the [[☃ definition 1]] is the same distance from the line as the [[☃ definition 2]], but on the other side.



[[☃ image 1]]

In other words, the line of reflection is the perpendicular bisector between any pair of corresponding points in the image and the pre-image.

options.definition: The figure *after* one or more transformations
The original figure *before* any transformations

options.alt: Point R is reflected across a line to form point R prime. Segment R R prime is perpendicular to the line.

hints.content:
We want to reflect $Q(3,-4)$ across the $x$-axis.  



[[☃ image 1]]

Point $Q$ is $4$ units directly below the $x$-axis, so $Q'$ will be $4$ units above the axis and have the same $x$-coordinate as $Q$.

Algebraically, this means a reflection across the $x$-axis is the transformation $(x,y) \to (x,-y)$.

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Point Q is at three, negative four.

hints.content:
$\begin{align}
Q &\to Q'
\\\\
(x,y) &\to (x,-y)
\\\\
(3, -4) &\to (3,-(-4))
\end{align}$

**The coordinates of $Q'$ are $(3, 4)$.**

This is how it looks graphically:



[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Point Q is at three, negative four. The point is reflected across the x-axis to form a new point at three, four labeled Q prime. Both points are four units from the x axis.

Point $D'$ is the image of $D(-2, 1)$ under a reflection across the $x$-axis.

**What are the coordinates of $D'$?**

$($ [[☃ numeric-input 1]] $,$ [[☃ numeric-input 2]] $)$

hints.content:
We want to reflect $D(-2, 1)$ across the $x$-axis.  



[[☃ image 1]]

Point $D$ is $1$ units directly above the $x$-axis, so $D'$ will be $1$ units below the axis and have the same $x$-coordinate as $D$.

Algebraically, this means a reflection across the $x$-axis is the transformation $(x,y) \to (x,-y)$.

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Point D is at negative two, one.

hints.content:
A reflection moves a point perpendicularly across a line, so that the [[☃ definition 1]] is the same distance from the line as the [[☃ definition 2]], but on the other side.



[[☃ image 1]]

In other words, the line of reflection is the perpendicular bisector between any pair of corresponding points in the image and the pre-image.

options.definition: The figure *after* one or more transformations
The original figure *before* any transformations

options.alt: Point R is reflected across a line to form point R prime. Segment R R prime is perpendicular to the line.

hints.content:
$\begin{align}
D &\to D'
\\\\
(x,y) &\to (x,-y)
\\\\
(-2, 1) &\to (-2,-(1))
\end{align}$

**The coordinates of $D'$ are $(-2, -1)$.**

This is how it looks graphically:  



[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Point D is at negative two, one. The point is reflected across the x-axis to form a new point at negative two, negative one. Both points are one unit from the x axis.
